prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 3627 CO (1-0) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal involves mapping the CO (1-0) line at 1.5" resolution in the central 30" of NGC 3627 in order to measure the sizes, line widths and CO luminosities of the clouds. We simultaneously observe continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3x10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at ~3-sigma in CO (1-0). The typical linewidths of clouds of this size are ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures in CO (1-0) of ~4 K. Therefore we require rms of ~1 K in this observation. However, given the short on source time relative to the required overheads , we instead aim for 0.2 K rms with minimal increase in observing time (from ~20 to ~30 minutes).

Typical linewidths of molecular clouds at 60 pc resolution are <10 km/s and the galaxies rotation covers several hundred km/s in the center. The 1.5 km/s resolution (with 2x spectral averaging) is high enough to adequately sample even the narrowest lines while the velocity coverage is broad enough to cover the full rotation curve.

The resolution of 1.5" is necessary to resolve ~60 pc scales in NGC 3627 (D=9.4 Mpc). The largest angular scale is set by the extent of the CO emission at a given frequency and due to the large velocity gradients in the galaxy centers is <5".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4321 CO (1-0) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal involves mapping the CO (1-0) line at 1" resolution in the central 30" of NGC 4321 in order to measure the sizes, line widths and CO luminosities of the clouds. We simultaneously observe continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3x10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at ~3-sigma in CO (1-0). The typical linewidths of clouds of this size are ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures in CO (1-0) of ~4 K. Therefore we require rms of ~1 K in this observation. However, given the short on source time relative to the required overheads , we instead aim for 0.2 K rms with a small increase in observing time to match sensitivity with NGC 3351 and 3627.

Typical linewidths of molecular clouds at 60 pc resolution are <10 km/s and the galaxies rotation covers several hundred km/s in the center. The 1.5 km/s resolution (with 2x spectral averaging) is high enough to adequately sample even the narrowest lines while the velocity coverage is broad enough to cover the full rotation curve.

The resolution of 1" is necessary to resolve ~60 pc scales in NGC 4321 (D=14.3 Mpc). The largest angular scale is set by the extent of the CO emission at a given frequency and due to the large velocity gradients in the galaxy centers is <5".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 3627 C18O (2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal involves mapping the C18O (2-1) line at 1.5" resolution in the central 30" of NGC 3627. To cover the area of interest, we employ a small mosaic with 7 pointings. We simultaneously observe the 13CO (2-1) line and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect and resolve a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3 x 10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at 3-sigma in the C18O (2-1) line. The typical size and FWHM line-width of a cloud of this mass are ~60 pc and ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures Tb ~4 K in CO (1-0). In calculating the necessary sensitivity for the C18O lines, we use our Cycle 2 NGC 3351 observation as a guide. That observation had rms sensivity of 0.02 K. In C18O we detect all GMCs seen in 13CO (2-1) at S/N ~3 or higher, which is adequate for our science goals.

Typical linewidths of molecular clouds at 60 pc resolution are <10 km/s and the galaxies rotation covers several hundred km/s in the center. The 1.5 km/s resolution (with 2x spectral averaging) is high enough to adequately sample even the narrowest lines while the velocity coverage is broad enough to cover the full rotation curve.

The resolution of 1.5" is necessary to resolve ~60 pc scales in NGC 3627 (D=9.4 Mpc). The largest angular scale is set by the extent of the CO emission at a given frequency and due to the large velocity gradients in the galaxy centers is <5".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect and resolve a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3 x 10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at 3-sigma in the C18O (2-1) line. The typical size and FWHM line-width of a cloud of this mass are ~60 pc and ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures Tb ~4 K in CO (1-0). In calculating the necessary sensitivity for the C18O lines, we use our Cycle 2 NGC 3351 observation as a guide. That observation had rms sensivity of 0.02 K. In C18O we detect all GMCs seen in 13CO (2-1) at S/N ~3 or higher, which is adequate for our science goals.

Typical linewidths of molecular clouds at 60 pc resolution are <10 km/s and the galaxies rotation covers several hundred km/s in the center. The 1.3 km/s resolution is high enough to adequately sample even the narrowest lines while the velocity coverage is broad enough to cover the full rotation curve.

The resolution of 1" is necessary to resolve ~60 pc scales in NGC 4321 (D=14.3 Mpc). The largest angular scale is set by the extent of the CO emission at a given frequency and due to the large velocity gradients in the galaxy centers is <5".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 3627 C18O (3-2) map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal involves mapping the C18O (3-2) line at 1.5" resolution in the central 30" of NGC 3627. To cover the area of interest, we employ a small mosaic with 14 pointings. We simultaneously observe 13CO (3-2) and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect and resolve a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3 x 10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at 3-sigma in the C18O (3-2) line. The typical size and FWHM line-width of a cloud of this mass are ~60 pc and ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures Tb ~4 K in CO (1-0). In calculating the necessary sensitivity for the C18O lines, we use our Cycle 2 NGC 3351 observation as a guide. That observation had rms sensivity of 0.02 K. In C18O (2-1) we detect all GMCs seen in 13CO (2-1) at S/N ~3 or higher, which is adequate for our science goals.

Typical linewidths of molecular clouds at 60 pc resolution are <10 km/s and the galaxies rotation covers several hundred km/s in the center. The 1.7 km/s resolution (with 4x spectral averaging) is high enough to adequately sample even the narrowest lines while the velocity coverage is broad enough to cover the full rotation curve.

The resolution of 1.5" is necessary to resolve ~60 pc scales in NGC 3627 (D=9.4 Mpc). The largest angular scale is set by the extent of the CO emission at a given frequency and due to the large velocity gradients in the galaxy centers is <5".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 3351 C18O (3-2) map

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to detect and resolve a typical MW GMC with a mass of ~3 x 10^5 Msun (i.e. similar to the Orion GMC) at 3-sigma in the C18O (3-2) line. The typical size and FWHM line-width of a cloud of this mass are ~60 pc and ~10 km/s. Typical MW clouds are observed to have peak brightness temperatures Tb ~4 K in CO (1-0). In calculating the necessary sensitivity for the C18O lines, we use our Cycle 2 NGC 3351 observation as a guide. That observation had rms sensivity of 0.02 K. In C18O we detect all GMCs seen in 13CO (2-1) at S/N ~3 or higher, which is adequate for our science goals.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to take a key step in understanding what physical processes control the CO-to-H2 conversion factor by using ALMA to characterize molecular gas properties in nearby galaxy centers where we observe low, starburst-like Xco. We will observe 12CO (1-0); 13CO and C18O (2-1) and (3-2); and dust continuum at matched GMC-scale (60pc) resolution. The spectacular sensitivity and resolution of ALMA make these faint diagnostics easily obtainable in nearby galaxies for the first time. In particular, the ability to measure multiple rotational levels of optically thin C18O emission lets us self-consistently measure cloud masses and excitation temperatures. Using these observations we will test several hypotheses for why Xco is low in these regions: (1) enhanced temperature and/or decreased density in virialized giant molecular clouds (GMCs), (2) CO emission from molecular gas not associated with GMCs or (3) GMCs that are unbound or under external pressure. The study we propose is the necessary, timely and feasible next step towards understanding Xco and will provide crucial information for future studies attempting to measure molecular gas masses in galaxies across the Universe.
